"Please recognize the child as it is, as it is!"

It is one of the good words that you should have heard or read at least once in
parental education or child education.
When I heard or read it, I nodded when I heard or read it, but there are many
people who say how to apply this in a relationship with a child doesn't really
touch. That is why many parents say that it is difficult to practice because
they don't know how to do it specifically.

What on earth does "respecting children as they are" mean and how can they be
applied in a relationship with them?

The method is simple.
You just have to acknowledge your child's feelings.

Recognizing emotions is the first step in a concrete practice method
of'acknowledging the existence of a child as it is.'
It is easy for parents to stand in their position now and see and judge their
child's emotions.
It takes practice and effort to consciously look at the child's emotions from
the child's point of view in order to recognize'Oh, you are now~ 00'.

Dad put honey in warm water to feed the child. He handed the cup of honey to the
child because he wanted it to be cool enough to eat. The child opened his mouth
a little and yelled that it was hot, and Dad once again took honey water. After
drinking it, he said, "What's hot? It's all cold! Now, nothing really is hot~",
and he gave the cup of honey again to the child. He looked at it again carefully
and screamed that it was still hot. I wanted to eat it, but I was so hot that I
couldn't eat and waited. I was angry and annoyed.

Everyone wants to be recognized.
The small size of a child does not mean that the amount of emotion the child
feels is also small.

<Do this!> First, you just have to admit it. "Oh, it's hot? Dad looked like it
was cool, but it's still hot for you" "Dad will cool it down quickly~ Hoho,
hoohoo~" If you cry while crying?"It takes time to cool down, and crying doesn't
cool down quickly~" The child doesn't stop with this healing. It only shows a
more grumpy reaction. Even in such a case, let's admit it. "I want to try it
quickly, but it's hot so it's hot right away. Isn't it hard to wait until you
can't eat and cool more?"

There is another advantage to acknowledging your child's feelings like this.
That is, parents consume less energy.
Don't run out of energy by saying,'Is you right, am I right?'
This makes it easier for the child to calm down, and the parent can move on to
the next step.
(next step: telling you how to respond-act appropriately-when you feel an
emotion)

What parents want to say must be done after acknowledging the child’s heart
first.
It is well communicated to the child and is heard by the child.
Open your child's ears so they can hear you, and then tell them what you want to
say.
"It takes time to cool down~, what should we wait while our honey water cools
down?"
The warm finish that the honey water was cool enough and ate deliciously while
this conversation came and went!~^^

Recognizing the child's emotions as they are is the first step in a concrete
practice method that acknowledges the child's existence as it is. Recognizing
and responding to your child's emotions allows them to perceive their emotions
and learn how to respond appropriately when feelings are felt.

Everyone wants to be recognized, and a child's small size doesn't mean that the
child's emotions are small.

First, admit to the pain when a child cries because he or she is sick. How do we
react when a child falls or bumps and cries because he is sick? Often, we try to
soothe and calm our child by saying that it is okay. Esau isn't that big of a
``big thing,'' but it may seem that the child is screaming unusually. If the
child doesn't know his or her heart, he expresses it more strongly to help the
other person know. Don't you know? It doesn't seem like this much. If she wants
her mom to know how sick I am, she'll have to cry louder!!!' This kind of
psychology works. So please admit it first. Please check the pain that the child
complains of by patting the back of the crying child, saying, "It hurts a lot?",
"I see you crying like this, and it looks like it is a lot of pain". Likewise,
the child is sad. Second, when you say that your child is scared, please admit
that it is scary. Don't ignore or reduce your child's feelings by saying, "Well,
what's that scary? I'm not scared at all". I feel scared, but my parents say
it's not. If ignored, the child is confused: perceive what they are feeling and
give them guidelines on how to behave appropriately. If you acknowledge and
respond, you can move on to the next setp. "It's scary to do 00, then let's hold
hands with mom?" (Otherwise,'What's scary' →'I'm scared~'' → Oh my~ I'm not
scared at all, Let's go~'→'I hate it, ah ah ah' repeats...) And if you don't
understand the feelings your child is feeling, ask what kind of thoughts you're
feeling. Judging by my standards is NO! When a child was young, when he entered
the beach, he didn't say "It's scary". "Hmm? Are you scared of stepping on the
sand?" (Mom) “Yes, I’m scared” (Child) “Joon-ah, what kind of thoughts are you
scared?” (Mom) “Sand goes into my feet~” (Child) “Joon-ah, it’s not scary that
sand gets into my feet, it’s uncomfortable Jun-i is worried that there will be
sand on her feet. You can brush it off or wash it off~ :)" (Mom) Let's correct
the expressions the child is saying and tell him how to solve the concerns. I
ran into the sandy beach. ^^ Third, when a child is unfamiliar, please admit
that unfamiliarity. Seeing a child who greets well and a child who is praised by
others makes me proud from the perspective of parents~^^ As a child with good
home education As a result, parents are proud of themselves. Different children
have different times to adjust to unfamiliar environments and strangers. Some
children need more time. So did my child, because when I met a stranger, I was
nervous and frozen. And let me know. "Let's say hello the next time we meet ^^"
If you don't force it, you'll see a slow but slowly changing child. Don't start
expecting a perfect look from the beginning. Children repeat countless times.
Fourth, please cherish what your child cherishes with you through practice and
time. If your child treats a small toy doll that looks decent and tries to carry
it with you anywhere, the mother sees it. Please admit it even if it looks like
it is, because it is an object that may seem insignificant on the outside, but
it is a precious thing that has an important meaning to a child. By recognizing
and responding to your child's emotions like this, he or she can perceive his or
her emotions and learn how to react appropriately when they feel them.
